case_name: State of Tamil Nadu v. Publishers of text-books

facts.text: Civil Appeals numbered 557 to 575 of 1971 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. No. 557 to 575 of 1971. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals arose from judgment and order dated September 3, 1970 of Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 768, 1465 and 1483 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 3, 1970 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 768, 1465 and 1483 of 1970.

facts.text: 22 Writ Petitions were filed in the High Court of Madras by publishers of text-books for Government Schools, District Board and Municipal Council Schools.

anchor.surface_text: 22 Writ Petitions were filed in the High Court of Madras by publishers of text-books for Government Schools, Distt. Board and Municipal Council Schools challenging

facts.text: Publishers challenged directions in D.O. letter No. 454582/E5/69, Education, dated 12th August 1969, addressed to District Collectors and Local Board authorities.

anchor.surface_text: challenging the directions of the Deputy Secretary to Government Education Department, contained in his D.O. letter No. 454582/ E5/69, Education, dated 12th August 1969,

facts.text: Directions required District Collectors and Local Board authorities to intimate to publishers that books prescribed for 1969-70 would no longer be prescribed after end of school year.

anchor.surface_text: addressed to District Collectors and Local Board authorities that they should intimate to the publishers of the books which are prescribed for the year 1969-70 that after the end of the School year they will no longer be prescribed.

facts.text: A Division Bench of the High Court allowed the Writ Petitions.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court allowed the Writ Petitions. From this decision, 19 appeals are before us by certificate.

facts.text: 19 appeals are before the Supreme Court by certificate.

anchor.surface_text: From this decision, 19 appeals are before us by certificate. It appears that the Government of Tamil Nadu in furtherance of its policy

facts.text: Government of Tamil Nadu intended to nationalise text-books for schools and publish them through the Tamil Nadu Text Books Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Government of Tamil Nadu in furtherance of its policy to nationalise text-books for schools, was intending to publish them through the Tamil Nadu Text Books Corporation

facts.text: Impugned D.O. letter issued pursuant to nationalisation policy.

anchor.surface_text: pursuant to which it had issued the impugned O. letter. The writ petitions which are the subject matter of these appeals raise similar grounds

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 768/70 averred that impugned letter is illegal and void as contrary to Madras Educational Rules and Text-Book Committee Rules made under Article 162.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in that appeal, alleged that the impugned O. letter giving the aforesaid directions is illegal and void as being contrary to the Madras Educational Rules and the Text-Book Committee Rules made by the Governor of Tamil Nadu

facts.text: Publishers' business of publishing text-books seriously jeopardised and brought to standstill.

anchor.surface_text: in pursuance of the powers vested under Article 162 of the Constitution and affected respondents fundamental rights under Article 19 1 g of the Constitution inasmuch as his business of publishing TextBooks has been seriously

facts.text: Under rules, text-books once approved and selected remain current for three years.

anchor.surface_text: principles of natural justice have been violated in that under the rules once textbooks have been approved and selected for the schools and have been prescribed, they remained current for three years,

facts.text: Cancellation without notice and hearing causes heavy financial loss to publishers.

anchor.surface_text: as such to cancel this continuance for the remaining period without notice and without hearing would result in heavy financial loss

facts.text: Madras Education Rules and Text Book Committee Rules issued on November 26, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The rules relating to Madras text-books Committee which were issued on November 26, 1965, set out the objects of the Committee, its constitution,

facts.text: Rule 58 of Madras Education Rules states text-books shall not be changed within three years without approval.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 58 which deals with the text-books, states that a consolidated list of text-books authorised by the Government to be used under the several subjects is published annually in the Fort St. George Gazette that Managers of schools are, at liberty to select from the latest list such books as they may deem most suitable provided that the text-books so selected shall not be changed within three years

facts.text: Rule 2 of Text Book Committee Rules: any book approved retains approval for five years.

anchor.surface_text: In Rule 2, it is provided that any book approved for use in recognised schools as text-book shall retain its approval for five years

facts.text: Government reserves right to forbid or prescribe use of any book in recognised schools.

anchor.surface_text: The Government, however, reserve to itself the right to forbid or to prescribe the use of any book or books in the recognised schools.

facts.text: High Court held that rules provide assurance to publishers for three years prescription.

anchor.surface_text: Nonetheless it was of the view that a publisher of text- books could proceed on the basis that he has some sort of assurance that once his books have been selected and prescribed as text-books, those books will remain to be so prescribed for three years,

facts.text: Supreme Court found rules are administrative instructions conceived in public interest, not conferring rights on publishers.

anchor.surface_text: Nor are they, as held by the High Court, designed to safeguard the interests of the publishers but are conceived in public interest.

facts.text: Impugned letter issued in exercise of power reserved under the rules.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned letter in this case can, therefore, be said to have been issued by the Government in exercise of the power reserved to it under those very rules.

facts.text: Rules aim to avoid hardship to students by not changing books frequently.

anchor.surface_text: All that the instructions that a book prescribed should not be changed for three years imply, as the High Court rightly recognised, is to avoid any hardship to the students.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was, therefore. entitled to invoke this principle in his favour in the instant case. The companytention urged on behalf of the State of Tamil Nadu that the rules being merely in the nature of administrative instructions, do number have the force of law and cannot be enforced in companyrts was negatived on two grounds, firstly, that even as an administrative instruction, if it has the force of representation which a publisher may well rely on and companymit himself to a certain position, it is number open to the authority to resile from it to his prejudice

arguments.court_reasoning: Analogous to State of Assam case where no writ maintainable for aided college rules

arguments.claim: rules traceable to executive power under Article 162; provide procedure which must be followed; cannot act contrary

anchor.surface_text: and secondly, that the rules referred to are obviously traceable to the executive power of the Government under Article 162 of the Constitution and provide for the procedure for registration of publishers, submission of books by them for approval and their selection, which books if approved and selected, are to be valid for a certain duration. For these reasons the High Court observed that even as an administrative instruction when it is companyified in that form, it is bound to be followed, and therefore, the executive cannot say that because they have the administrative power they are entitled to use and invoke such administrative power and act for the purpose of its adoption in individual cases companytrary to the generality and tenor of the rules.

arguments.claim: rules are administrative instructions for guidance of Department, confer no rights on publishers

anchor.surface_text: Nor are they, as held by the High Court, designed to safeguard the interests of the publishers but are conceived in public interest.

arguments.claim: under Rule 58, Government reserves right to forbid or prescribe use of any books notwithstanding three-year period

anchor.surface_text: Rule 58 which deals with the text-books, states that a companysolidated list of text-books authorised by the Government to be used under the several subjects is published annually in the Fort St. George Gazette that Managers of schools are, at liberty to select from the latest list such books as they may deem most suitable provided that the text-books so selected shall number be changed within three years

arguments.claim: Text Book Committee Rule 2 provides approval for five years but no rights conferred; Government at liberty to change

anchor.surface_text: In Rule 2, it is provided that any book approved for use in recognised schools as text-book shall retain its approval for five years and in Rule 30 it is provided that 11 text- books used in recognised schools shall be selected only from the approved list of text-books issued during the year excepting books published by or on behalf of the Government.

arguments.claim: three-year period is injunction to school managers to avoid hardship to students, not assurance to publishers

anchor.surface_text: All that the instructions that a book prescribed should not be changed for three years imply, as the High Court rightly recognised, is to avoid any hardship to the students.

arguments.claim: impugned letter issued in exercise of power reserved to Government under the rules

anchor.surface_text: The impugned letter in this case can, therefore, be said to have been issued by the Government in exercise of the power reserved to it under those very rules.

arguments.claim: no representation or assurance to publishers; they bear risk if books not sold

anchor.surface_text: When once it is accepted that those instructions do number companyfer any right on number create an interest in the publishers but are companyceived in the public interest and the Government has full liberty in the matter of approval as well as the power of companytrol over the kind of books that should be prescribed in the ,schools, the publishers cannot say that once they are prescribed they cannot be changed within the period for which they are stated to be current.

arguments.claim: in Indo-Afghan Agencies, representation made and acted upon; distinguishable as no representation here

anchor.surface_text: It is true that a representation can be made- to a person either directly or indirectly if it was intended to be made to him when it is brought to his numberice. But that is number the case here as it was in the Union of India Ors v. M s. Indo-Afghan Agencies Ltd. 1 , where under a scheme to increase exports of woollen textiles, as an incentive it was provided that an exporter will be granted certificates to import raw materials of a total amount equal to 100 of the f.o.b. value of his exports.

arguments.claim: State of Assam case analogous: no writ under Art 226 to enforce administrative rules for aided institutions

anchor.surface_text: The case which is more analogous to the one before us is The State of Assam and Another v. Ajit Kumar Sharma and Others 2  where a Constitution Bench of this Court which companysidered the claim of the teacher of a private College affiliated to the Gauhati University in Assam which received grants-in-aid from the State on certain companyditions set out in the form of Rules held that the was number entitled to maintain a Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The Madras Education Rules and the Text Book Committee Rules do not hold out any representation or even an assurance to the publishers that the books once prescribed will not be changed.

anchor.surface_text: There is in our view no warrant for concluding that the Madras Education Rules and the Text Book Committee Rules hold out any representation or even an assurance to the publishers that the books once prescribed will not be changed as contended by the respondents advocate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules are departmental instructions for guidance, no justification for assuming representation to publishers; estoppel rejected as no such holding out.

holdings.text: The rules are administrative instructions conceived in public interest and do not confer any rights on publishers or safeguard their interests.

anchor.surface_text: Nor are they, as held by the High Court, designed to safeguard the interests of the publishers but are conceived in public interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Perusal of rules shows they are departmental instructions; government at liberty to change list; not for publishers' benefit.

holdings.text: Under Rule 58 of Madras Education Rules, the Government reserves to itself the right to forbid or to prescribe the use of any book or books in the recognised schools notwithstanding the three-year period.

anchor.surface_text: The Government, however, reserve to itself the right to forbid or to prescribe the use of any book or books in the recognised schools.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit reservation in Rule 58 overrides non-change instruction for managers; applies to facts of impugned letter.

holdings.text: The impugned letter was issued by the Government in exercise of the power reserved to it under the rules.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned letter in this case can, therefore, be said to have been issued by the Government in exercise of the power reserved to it under those very rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules empower government to forbid or prescribe books; letter pursuant to nationalisation policy uses this power.

holdings.text: The instructions do not confer any right or create an interest in the publishers; publishers bear the risk if books are not sold.

anchor.surface_text: When once it is accepted that those instructions do not confer any right on or create an interest in the publishers but are conceived in the public interest and the Government has full liberty in the matter of approval as well as the power of control over the kind of books that should be prescribed in the schools, the publishers cannot say that once they are prescribed they cannot be changed within the period for which they are stated to be current.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No undertaking that books will be prescribed or required in numbers; selection only approves fitness, risk on publishers.

holdings.text: The three-year period for textbooks is an injunction to school managers to avoid hardship to students, not an assurance to publishers.

anchor.surface_text: All that the instructions that a book prescribed should not be changed for three years imply, as the High Court rightly recognised, is to avoid any hardship to the students.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose to prevent frequent changes causing student hardship (repeats, second-hand books); public interest.

holdings.text: Cancellation of prescription without notice does not violate natural justice as no rights or hearing required under rules for publishers.

anchor.surface_text: There is in our view no warrant for concluding that the Madras Education Rules and the Text Book Committee Rules hold out any representation or even an assurance to the publishers that the books once prescribed will not be changed as contended by the respondents advocate

holdings.reasoning_summary: No representation held out requiring hearing; rules confer no rights on publishers.

holdings.text: A writ petition under Article 226 is not maintainable to enforce administrative rules like these, analogous to State of Assam case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent analogy: no writ for aided institution rules; administrative instructions not enforceable by writ.

holdings.text: The policy of nationalisation and impugned directions do not violate Article 19(1)(g) as no fundamental right infringed.

anchor.surface_text: When once it is accepted that those instructions do not confer any right on or create an interest in the publishers but are conceived in the public interest and the Government has full liberty in the matter of approval as well as the power of control over the kind of books that should be prescribed in the schools, the publishers cannot say that once they are prescribed they cannot be changed within the period for which they are stated to be current.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No vested right or legitimate expectation; business risk inherent, state policy within executive power under Art 162.

holdings.text: Rules under Article 162 do not restrict government from acting contrary; full liberty retained.

anchor.surface_text: which in our view they are not, empower the managers subject to the approval of the authority concerned to change them within the period specified therein or the Government to forbid or prescribe the use of any book or books in the recognised schools.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules trace to Art 162 executive power but include reservation allowing override; not binding on government.

precedents.citation: Union of India Ors v. M s. Indo-Afghan Agencies Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: Union of India Ors v. M s. Indo-Afghan Agencies Ltd. 1 , where under a scheme to increase exports of woollen textiles, as an incentive it was provided that an exporter will be granted certificates to import raw materials of a total amount equal to 100 of the f.o.b. value of his exports.

precedents.case_name: Union of India v. Indo-Afghan Agencies Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Even executive or administrative schemes imposing obligations on authorities can be enforced by courts, and action without notice or opportunity is invalid
precedents.cited_holding: Action of Textile Commissioner reducing import entitlement without informing respondents or giving opportunity was bad and struck down

precedents.citation: Sankaranarayanan, etc. etc. v. The State of Kerala  2

anchor.surface_text: Sankaranarayanan, etc. etc. v. The State of Kerala  2 , and in an unreported decision in M s.  1  1968 2 S.C.R. 366.  2  1971 2 S.C.R. 361. Narinderchand Hemraj and Ors. V. Lt. Governor, Union Territory, Himachal Pradesh Ors.  1 , to both of which one of us  Hegde, J.  was a party.

precedents.cited_proposition: No question of representation by Government acted upon to detriment

precedents.citation: Narinderchand Hemraj and Ors. V. Lt. Governor, Union Territory, Himachal Pradesh Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: Narinderchand Hemraj and Ors. V. Lt. Governor, Union Territory, Himachal Pradesh Ors.  1 , to both of which one of us  Hegde, J.  was a party. In the former case it was pointed out that there is no question of any representation having been made by the Government which was acted upon to their detriment by the appellants.

precedents.case_name: Narinderchand Hemraj v. Lt. Governor, Union Territory, Himachal Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Court in Indo-Afghan did not hold Government incompetent to change scheme but estoppel applies if representation made and acted upon

precedents.citation: The State of Assam and Another v. Ajit Kumar Sharma and Others 2

anchor.surface_text: The State of Assam and Another v. Ajit Kumar Sharma and Others 2  where a Constitution Bench of this Court which considered the claim of the teacher of a private College affiliated to the Gauhati University in Assam which received grants-in-aid from the State on certain conditions set out in the form of Rules held that he was not entitled to maintain a Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: State of Assam v. Ajit Kumar Sharma
precedents.cited_proposition: No entitlement to writ under administrative rules for grants-in-aid; teacher not entitled to enforce rule on compulsory leave
precedents.cited_holding: Teacher of private college not entitled to maintain writ petition under Article 226 based on administrative rules

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
